content.body:
Mathieu Hofman I was wrong, `(async function f() { try { await import("data:text/javascript, throw new Error()") } catch (e) { return console.log("STACK", e.stack) } })()` doesn't leak the function name neither in Chrome nor in Firefox.

The error stack contains the function name only when the error is a CSP error, but in that case it throws fresh errors every time.

content.body: We really need to move the error stack proposal forward to put them within tc39 scope
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: We really need to move the error stack proposal forward to put them within tc39 scope

content.body: My understanding from comments from shu was that adding an error stack API wouldn't cause browsers to necessarily change how they expose non-standard information. I think you'd have to persuade them to make those changes more directly.

content.body: The main problem is that right now it's hard to talk about stacks in the spec, and what information can and cannot be exposed through them
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The main problem is that right now it's hard to talk about stacks in the spec, and what information can and cannot be exposed through them

content.body: We're seeing this with the ShadowRealm proposal, we're seeing it potentially with the lazy/deferred module loading.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: We're seeing this with the ShadowRealm proposal, we're seeing it potentially with the lazy/deferred module loading.
